channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
item.description: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The India A.I. Impact Summit unfolded across 120 acres in New Delhi this week, featuring more than 300 exhibitors and 500 sessions. Organizers expected about 250,000 participants and visitors.

item.title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
item.description: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Krolik
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: The BYD stand at an auto show in Shanghai last year. BYD’s stock has fallen over 35 percent since its peak last May.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.description: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Defense Department and Anthropic have been negotiating a contract over A.I. use by the Pentagon.

item.title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
item.description: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plane belonging to Donald J. Trump arrived at Palm Beach International Airport in 2023. Florida Republicans have advanced an effort to rename the airport “President Donald J. Trump International Airport.”

item.title: Workplace Inspections by OSHA Dropped Over a Six-Month Period of 2025
item.description: Labor advocates worry that the Trump administration is relaxing oversight of companies and increasing the potential for serious injuries and deaths.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has made efforts to roll back regulations for worker safety and protections, including plans to pull back a requirement that employers provide appropriate lighting at construction sites.

item.title: Edison Will Reduce Executive Bonuses as a Result of the Eaton Fire
item.description: Southern California Edison had said its electrical equipment most likely caused the blaze, which destroyed much of Altadena, a Los Angeles suburb.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pedro J. Pizarro, the president and chief executive of Edison International, the parent company of Southern California Edison, will take a pay cut totaling about half of the trims to executive compensation.

item.title: Etsy Sells Depop, a Secondhand Clothing App Popular With Gen Z, to eBay
item.description: The $1.2 billion deal comes as eBay looks to expand its appeal among younger users.
item.dc:creator: Niko Gallogly
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Depop, a secondhand clothing app, was acquired by Etsy in 2021 for $1.6 billion.

item.title: Fed Minutes Show No Rush to Restart Rate Cuts
item.description: Barring a rapid deterioration in the labor market or a significant cooling of inflation, the Federal Reserve appears poised for an extended hold.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, has stressed that the central bank will make decisions meeting by meeting.

item.title: What Do A.I. Chatbots Discuss Among Themselves? We Sent One to Find Out.
item.description: We interviewed our bot about what it learned on Moltbook, the A.I.-only social network.
item.dc:creator: Eve Washington

item.title: The New York Times Wins 3 Polk Awards
item.description: The Times was honored for its coverage of President Trump, the abuse of housekeepers and nannies in Saudi Arabia and brutality in New York prisons.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A New York Times investigation revealed that at least 274 Kenyan workers, mostly women, had died in Saudi Arabia in the past five years.

item.title: Kentucky Derby Operator Accused of Regulatory ‘Freeloading’
item.description: The Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority filed a complaint saying Churchill Downs Inc. is not paying its fair share to support inspections and testing.
item.dc:creator: Joe Drape
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kentucky Derby day at Churchill Downs in 2024. The Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority says Churchill Downs Inc. owes it $2.4 million in fees.

item.title: Elon Musk’s xAI Gets $3 Billion Investment From Saudi-Backed A.I. Firm
item.description: Humain, which was created by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman last year, said it made the investment just before xAI was acquired by SpaceX, Mr. Musk’s rocket company.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman with Elon Musk at a Saudi Arabia Investment forum at the Kennedy Center in Washington last year.

item.title: F.D.A. Reverses Decision and Agrees to Review Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: Moderna held further discussions with regulators and announced that the agency would accept the company’s application for approval of its flu vaccine that uses mRNA technology.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Ryan Remiorz/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Moderna’s vaccine production facility in Laval, Quebec.

item.title: How Crypto’s Lobbying Muscle May Save the Clarity Act
item.description: A market rout may have decimated the crypto industry. But its machine in Washington may power proposed regulation past concerned Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount, Grady McGregor and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brian Armstrong, the C.E.O. of Coinbase, has sounded more optimistic about a crypto measure that had stalled in the Senate after he raised some objections.

item.title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
item.description: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: Drivers for Uber, Lyft and other taxi services are often the biggest users of charging stations, like this one at Kennedy International Airport.

item.title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
item.description: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Naohiro Kimura/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange in 1986. In the 1980s and 1990s, yields on Japanese government bonds shifted rapidly alongside fluctuations in Japan’s overall economy.

item.title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
item.description: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Josh Haner/The New York Times
item.media:description: A reasonable person would understand that boneless wings are chicken nuggets coated in Buffalo sauce, a judge said on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
item.description: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi in Tokyo in October.

item.title: Goldman Sachs to Drop D.E.I. Criteria for Board Members
item.description: The move would be the Wall Street firm’s latest retreat from diversity mandates that its chief executive, David Solomon, had once made a priority.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell
item.media:credit: Tyrone Siu/Reuters
item.media:description: David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, had championed an effort to expand the bank’s traditionally white, male-dominated work force.

item.title: Are you a medical provider who has worked in an ICE detention facility? We want to hear from you.
item.description: We want to get a better picture of what medical care for immigrants in detention is like.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An ICE detention center in Dilley, Texas, in 2019.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, is among the Trump administration officials whose names appear in the Epstein files.

item.title: From 2001: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
item.description: She escaped the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, in which 146 of her co-workers perished, and dedicated the rest of her life to worker safety.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Martin

item.title: Bayer Agrees to Pay $7.25 Billion to Settle Roundup Lawsuits
item.description: The agreement, which still faces legal hurdles, would cover current and future claims that the weedkiller caused non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:credit: Regis Duvignau/Reuters
item.media:description: The weedkiller Roundup is used by farmers around the world.

item.title: Colbert Slams Trump Administration After CBS Pulls Talarico Interview
item.description: Stephen Colbert said he had to drop an interview with James Talarico from his Monday broadcast because of new F.C.C. guidance that targeted political interviews on late-night shows.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Michael Loccisano/Getty Images
item.media:description: Stephen Colbert was barred from airing an interview he had planned with State Representative James Talarico of Texas, a Democrat.

item.title: GQ Names Adam Baidawi as Its Top Editor
item.description: Mr. Baidawi, 35, replaces the magazine’s longtime editor Will Welch. He says he wants the magazine to be a “North Star of masculinity.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Billy Barraclough for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adam Baidawi previously led British GQ and was the deputy global editorial director for the magazine.

item.title: Paramount’s New Chance to Win Over Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: The takeover battle took a new turn on Tuesday as Warner Bros. Discovery reopened talks with its rebuffed suitor. But big questions still remain.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount has notched a big breakthrough in its efforts to restart merger talks with Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: Warner Bros. Discovery Restarts Deal Talks With Paramount
item.description: Paramount’s takeover bid was rejected in favor of Netflix, which wanted only the streaming and studio businesses. Paramount said it would pay more if negotiations were reopened.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount Pictures in Hollywood. Paramount has not publicly raised its offer from $30 a share.

item.title: Trump Sought Vast Budget Cuts. Congress Granted Few.
item.description: In a series of deals over the past three months, lawmakers rejected some of the president’s most aggressive attempts to whittle down the government.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congress has left intact a large set of federal programs that the White House tried to slash or eliminate this fiscal year.

item.title: With Niche Tech World References, Vibe Hopes Its Billboards Reach Start-Up Insiders
item.description: Billboards that wouldn’t make sense to people outside the tech industry have become common in the Bay Area. One company took the microtargeting game to another level.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha and Minh Connors

item.title: Anderson Cooper Is Leaving ’60 Minutes’
item.description: Mr. Cooper said in a statement that he was leaving as a correspondent for the show to focus on his CNN program and spend more time with his children.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Adrienne Grunwald for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anderson Cooper has been a correspondent on the CBS newsmagazine for almost 20 years.

item.title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
item.description: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Moderna says it plans to pull back on late-stage studies of some of its experimental vaccines.

item.title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
item.description: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Luisa Jung

item.title: How the H-1B Visa Debate Is Driving a Wave of Racism Against South Asians
item.description: A dispute over the impact of H-1B visas on U.S. workers has been overshadowed by racist rhetoric, with troubling echoes of the great replacement conspiracy theory.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Frisco, Texas, one-third of the population is of Asian heritage.

item.title: The Quiet Architect of Trump’s Global Trade War
item.description: Jamieson Greer, a low-key lawyer from a working-class background, is rewriting the rules of the global economy at the president’s behest.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, has quietly navigated the demands of an unpredictable president.

item.title: How a Trump Tax Break Rescued Horse Racing
item.description: Owners spent nearly $1.5 billion last year on racehorses, a big increase over 2024. A new tax provision allows them to immediately deduct the full cost of the purchase.
item.dc:creator: Joe Drape
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times

item.title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
item.description: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Chinese tour group in Tokyo last year. A decline in visitors has followed remarks by the Japanese prime minister suggesting Japan would come to Taiwan’s defense in the event of a Chinese invasion.

item.title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warner Bros. Discovery has until Feb. 25 to respond to Paramount’s latest proposal.

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.description: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Complaints to the U.S. Department of Transportation about the start-stop feature peaked in 2022 and fell almost in half by 2024.

item.title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
item.description: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, River Akira Davis and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Heather Diehl/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Washington Monument illuminated on New Year’s Eve. In December, President Trump announced a campaign to organize celebrations of America’s 250th birthday.

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
item.description: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Pictures
item.media:description: Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi in “Wuthering Heights.” The director, Emerald Fennell, and Ms. Robbie, a co-producer, went with Warner Bros. because it promised a wide theatrical release.

item.title: Will 2026 Be the Year of the ‘Soonicorn’?
item.description: As venture capital funding pours into start-ups large and small, more firms are pitching themselves as the next big thing.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Melanie Lambrick

item.title: What C.E.O.s Are Worried About
item.description: Fractured politics, disruptive technologies and a distrust in institutions are making it harder to focus on the traditional tasks of growing sales and profits.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.category: Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America
item.media:credit: Pete Ryan

item.title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
item.description: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ring doorbell security camera on the front of a building in New York. The planned integration of those cameras to activate a search function gave rise to criticism after a Super Bowl ad.

item.title: How ICE Is Pushing Tech Companies to Identify Protesters
item.description: The DHS is flooding social media companies with administrative subpoenas to identify accounts that are protesting ICE. Social media companies have pushed back but are largely complying. Our tech reporter, Sheera Frenkel, explains.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel, Christina Thornell, Valentina Caval, Thomas Vollkommer, Jon Hazell and June Kim

item.title: Software? No Way. We’re an A.I. Company Now!
item.description: As their stocks tank, software makers are rebranding themselves as A.I. innovators. Sparkle emojis are everywhere, but some efforts have been more successful than others.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler
item.media:credit: Javier Palma

item.title: Can You Rely on A.I. to Translate Love?
item.description: A.I. translation has become a huge industry, but how accurate is it? Our tech reporter, Kashmir Hill, explores its successes and failures through a couple who relies on of A.I. translation to communicate.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill, Gilad Thaler, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Jon Hazell and Joey Sendaydiego

item.title: T.S.A. Workers Brace for Another Shutdown They Didn’t Cause
item.description: As Congress leaves town without funding their department, airport security officers wonder, “How many more times am I going to be able to do this?”
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shutdown is especially hard for T.S.A. employees this time around, because many are just recovering from the financial strain they suffered during last year’s 43-day shutdown.

item.title: Sick Detainees Describe Poor Care at CoreCivic ICE Facilities
item.description: Problems at detention centers operated by CoreCivic extend far beyond recent measles outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amalia, a young girl who became dangerously ill at a CoreCivic detention center, with her parents after she was released last week.

item.title: The 2026 Milan Olympics Has Its Eyes on Grana Padano
item.description: Grana Padano cheese is trying to capture some of the international spotlight on Italy, appearing on billboards and social media — and in high-protein muffins for athletes.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Grana Padano, which monks began making in the 12th century, is everywhere at the 2026 Olympics.

item.title: How A.I. Salaries Are Causing Couples to Rethink Money in Relationships
item.description: The artificial intelligence frenzy is creating personal fortunes rarely seen in modern technology and changing people’s attitudes about fairness and money in relationships.
item.dc:creator: Kami Rieck
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
item.media:description: Akash Samant is a co-founder of Coverflow, an A.I. start-up that serves insurance agencies. He hopes to make enough money from his company going public or being acquired to give his girlfriend the choice to opt out of working.
